author: gakonst
content: What do we think impact of Verkle will be in historical/live execution & simulation times? I saw a note about 10% w/o proof generation slowdown, how expensive is proof generation? We probably need to make it as fast or faster than status quo, same for gas pricing, right?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> well status quo doesn't have proofs so unfortunately we can't be faster than that

author: gakonst
content: Understood, broader point I think holds? Esp if it has impact for timing games during block production? I think I heard someone mention something about decoupling proofs from the header

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> for a typical block we're talking 200 ms or so: https://github.com/crate-crypto/go-ipa/pull/63

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> why would it impact timing games? it just makes block prod slightly slower for everyone right?

author: gakonst
content: I haven't thought deeply about it and you're obviously closer, my general understanding is that anything that makes block production slower means that you're more likely to get reorged because of blocks arriving later in the slot (due to "Honest Reorgs")

author: _shemnon
content: My heretical opinion is that we should segregate transaction ordering from state root calculation.  Order in one CL block, state root values in the next.  All TXes must still be valid (including required balances) but that can be validated with a flat DB of the whole state.

author: _shemnon
content: Also, state witness comes with the order.

author: potuz
content: This makes the pipelining of block processing much more efficient IMO, since it splits the time when both CL and EL are doing critical work. Currently we both process blocks at around 2 seconds into the slot and then sit idling for a while

author: potuz
content: Only reason I'd be skeptical is that ePBS already solves this and I'm very hopeful we will have this soon

author: _shemnon
content: Will ePBS be able to handle verkle?  200ms could break a lot of things when it's  5% of the window.
